text: Jeffrey you Jenna DS is a rarity in
contemporary American fiction a highly
serious literary novelist whose books
are also enormous ly popular
he's written just two novels his first
novel The Virgin Suicides was made into
a much discussed film his second novel
Middlesex when the Pulitzer Prize and
remains one of the best-selling of all
contemporary American novels Jeffrey you
Jenna tease visited The Times recently
and we talked about his fiction the
reissue of The Virgin Suicides
and also about his hometown Detroit
which is undergone so much change in
recent years
Jeffrey you Jenna tease your first novel
The Virgin Suicides
has just been re-released it was
published in 1993 I believe how does
that novel look to you now how does it
look now well it's um I like to cover
the new cover respectively I think it's
kind of dangerous to go back to your old
work and read it extensively because one
of two things can happen either you're
terribly impressed with your early work
and you're not writing as well now which
would depress you or you find that you
actually weren't as good as you thought
you were at the time so I tried to keep
a kind of healthy distance on it so The
Virgin Suicides is a remarkable fable
also a realistic depiction in its way of
suburban life at a certain time who were
you when you conceived that novel and
wrote it who I was was a 33 year old
executive secretary at the Academy of
American poets writing that book at
night for two hours every night on the
weekends and often at work and I was
finally fired from the job for writing
The Virgin Suicides on the sly I
actually have a package of manuscript
pages that are that bear the letterhead
of the American Academy of American
poets because I would pretend to type a
letter to John Ashbery or James Merrill
and actually type scenes from the novel
so that's who I was I was a struggling
first-time novelist one interesting
question that comes up with your work is
particularly in Middlesex is you write a
great deal about the immigrant
experience it's the Greek American
experience how many literary forebears
did you have writing in this country
during the kind of fiction that you
wanted to write uh absolutely none in
terms of Greek forebears I think
probably the influences on my work our
Jewish writers Bello and and Philip Roth
and writers like that whose experience
always rang true to me the idea of
parents or grandparents from Europe
perhaps not so literate working very
hard to give their kids a chance in
America that that all seemed very much
like my own childhood one character in
both your first two novels different
though they are is Detroit and its
suburbs some have said you're the
laureate of Detroit every time I go back
to Detroit you know this is this German
word ruinen lost which is the pleasure
of ruins and there's the concept is that
you go to these places that are falling
apart and and they fill you with this
kind of tragic sense of not just the
place but of life itself and that's what
that's what comes over me when I go to
Detroit my whole childhood that the city
was just falling apart little by little
I was born in the city in 1960 and then
the riots happened in 67 and then after
that just little by little you saw the
city just getting shabbier and sort of
crumbling now what's happened is that
it's just vanishing and in large swaths
they're bulldozing so much of the city
about 30 to 40 percent of it is now
empty land so that's what I noticed when
when I go there is just my city and
parts of it just being erased are you
then still a Detroit writer is that
where you will return for your
inspiration and your story so the way
Roth is done with Newark or can you see
yourself moving outward well I the only
other place I've written about
extensively not extensively but a little
bit of Chicago which is not such a
different city than Detroit I can
understand Chicago immediately from
having grown up in Detroit if I moved to
San Francisco in California I don't
understand the society out there I don't
know
the people that live there and how the
cogs work so I don't think I would write
about California I think I will return
to Detroit in a lot of my books but not
not only I mean Roth has his little bits
of New York and his little bits of
Chicago and Bella wrote his New York
novels so hey you know I'll give myself
a little bit of wanderlust in my fiction
Middlesex reads like the work of quite
different author in some respects from
the Virgin Suicides what are you working
on now we're going to see another
protein transformation I hope so
actually I've changed my work quite a
bit since Middlesex I think when you
finish a book especially one you've
worked on a long time you just want to
get out of that atmosphere in that mode
so I've been moving toward an even more
realistic tightly dramatized kind of
fiction I've written published a few
stories in The New Yorker that are more
in this mode generally my work has gone
from a preoccupation with language and I
think the Virgin Suicides represents
that where it's really about the voice
of the novel Middlesex was where I
taught myself how to plot it's extremely
heavily over plotted novel the most and
and now I'm working on deeper
characterization deeper psychological
portraits of my characters so that's the
trajectory of my work is going on and
what would goes along with that it seems
as it is a kind of deepening realism
well you're the rare literary author who
also has a devoted and large following
I'm sure our listeners and viewers would
like to know when we might see this
third now the new one well my editor was
also asking me that it's I'm supposed to
finish in a couple of years from now I
think my contract says but I'm doing
what doing my best
thanks so much Jeff for your Genevieve
thank you
